Hell, that's OO.

It's a philosophical difference.

Cedric believes that a =
test class is an instance by itself, which will
then have several test meth=
ods called on it in succession. This is the
way TestNG works, and it's the =
way that NUnit works as well. This
makes it easy to share common data betwe=
en the test methods, as they
simply are the same instance. However, it expo=
ses you to lack of test
isolation, which may mean that the tests are not or=
der independent,
and also affect your abilty to run them concurrently.

Ken=
t Beck obviously believes that each test _method_ is worthy of
being its ow=
n instance. This means that the tests _can_ be run in any
order, in paralle=
l, etc, but means that they can not use instance data
to share state.

Ther=
e is no right or wrong choice here - they represent solutions that
accept d=
ifferent balances of the competing forces. It is possible that
one or the o=
ther is more intuitive (certainly Cedric's argued that in
the past), but a =
counter-intuitive solution isn't necessarily _wrong_
just because it's coun=
ter-intuitive - that's what documentation is
for.
